slidelink.displaytext: Why Being A Good Neighbour Is Important?
Ways To Be a Good Neighbour
Scenario: This is your neighbourhood at 6 A.M. What should you should not be seeing or hearing that early in the morning? (Click the part of the image that best answers the question.)
When it comes to keeping your neighbourhood clean, what would you not expect to see here? (Click the part of the image that best answers the question and then click SUBMIT)
You have decided to build a shed in your backyard and you do not need permission from anyone to make it.
Scenario: You have a fire pit in your backyard. You are allowed to use it whenever you want because you own it and it is on your property.
What can you do to avoid accumulating waste on your property. (Drag the correct answer to the top.)
What can you do to avoid accumulation waste on your property. (Drag the correct answer to the top.)

Matching Type. Before getting an animal you should be aware of what it takes to make it a good member of your family and your neighbourhood. (Drag each puzzle piece on the right to its correct match on the left.)
Homeowners need __________ to cover risks and protect their home, property, and community.
What number should you call in case of emergency?
The emergency number should be used to call which of the options below? (Select all that apply.)

search.slidetext: this guide is designed to honour the spirit of respect and empathy we encourage our families to build with the people next door, your neighbours! by doing so, not only do you build stronger communities, you uphold the homeowner partnership agreement set forth by habitat for humanity new brunswick. thank you to our partners greater fredericton social innovation and civic tech fredericton volunteers for creating this online experience. introduction course duration: 20 minutes

objectives comply with municipal regulations (e.g., noise, pets, permits), and ensure you are equipped with necessary emergency contacts and insurance knowledge. recognize the importance of being a good neighbour by respecting others’ rights, privacy, and property, while contributing to a welcoming and cooperative neighbourhood. understand how maintaining your home, yard, and waste management practices promotes safety, preserves property value, and reflects pride of ownership. in this module you will:

why being a good neighbour is important being a good neighbour more than rules and regulations being a good neighbour is being considerate of the people who live next door and on your street. it means making an effort to be friendly by introducing yourself if you are new to the neighbourhood, or welcoming new neighbours if you are already a resident. get to know your neighbours and their lifestyle so you can be considerate of their living schedule as well as your own. why being a good neighbour is important

show pride of ownership by keeping your yard neat and clean and the exterior of your home properly maintained. ensure garbage is stored in bins with lids and put to the curb regularly to avoid attracting pests. control your pets and pick up their droppings from your neighbours’ lawn. practice courtesy by avoiding profanity when outside. learn about local by-laws and licensing. be conscious of creating excessive noise at all times, but especially when your neighbours are sleeping. respect your neighbour's rights and privacy. teach your children to participate in good neighbour practices. be willing to help when you see a neighbour in need because good neighbours build good communities. ways to be a good neighbour

practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership have permits for construction work have permits for construction work have permits for construction work respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair practice responsible pet ownership. leash animals when in public and clean up after your pet. being a responsible pet owner means ensuring your pet’s behavior doesn’t negatively impact others. keeping pets leashed in public prevents accidents or unwanted interactions, while cleaning up after them keeps shared spaces clean, safe, and pleasant for everyone. title 01 practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership have permits for construction work have permits for construction work respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair obtain building permits prior to beginning construction work and in accordance with municipal by-laws. permits ensure that construction projects meet safety standards and zoning regulations, helping to protect property values and public welfare. starting work without a permit can lead to fines, delays, or having to redo the work to comply with codes. remember to get permission from habitatnb before starting any building or renovation projects keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good evening and overnight hours. being mindful of volume levels, especially with music, parties, or machinery, helps foster a respectful and comfortable environment for your neighbors. title 01 practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership have permits for construction work have permits for construction work have permits for construction work respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair following local traffic and parking regulations ensures the safety and accessibility of streets for all users, including pedestrians, cyclists, and emergency vehicles. illegally parked vehicles or speeding can create hazards and inconvenience for others in the area. title 01 practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership have permits for construction work have permits for construction work have permits for construction work respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect the excessive noise by-law respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws respect traffic and parking by-laws regular maintenance of your home and yard not only preserves property value but also contributes to a clean, safe, and visually appealing neighborhood. addressing issues like broken steps, peeling paint, or overgrown lawns helps prevent larger problems and shows consideration for your community. title 01 keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership practice responsible pet ownership have and parking by-laws keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair keep your home and property in good repair ways to be a good neighbour five key things property owners must do

every homeowner has the right to the reasonable enjoyment of their home and property. because of this, there are codes and by-laws in place which protects all residents of your community from unkempt homes and yards, excessive noise, property encroachment and trespassing. respecting your neighbours' rights and privacy will ensure you foster positive relationships with everyone in your community. respecting neighbours’ rights and privacy

incorrect good neighbours control pets, clean up after them, get permits for building, contain trash properly, and respect noise rules. don't let pets roam or put trash elsewhere. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct good neighbours control pets, clean up after them, get permits for building, contain trash properly, and respect noise rules. don't let pets roam or put pride of ownership maintaining your property pride of ownership is reflected in the way you choose to care for your home. it means maintaining your lawn in the summer and your driveway and sidewalk in the winter. it's putting away children's toys at the end of each day and making sure your lawn is free from litter and debris. habitat for humanity new brunswick requires you to protect your investment, your home, through thoughtful maintenance that will help your home maintain and grow in value. by showing pride in ownership, you are representing habitatnb in a positive way that will ensure we are offered future opportunities to build more homes in your area. all of these things keep you aligned with our partnership agreement. when you become a homeowner, you must follow the standards set forth by your municipality which upholds the safety and welfare of not only you, but the general public. pride of ownership

view cards again view cards again view cards again view cards again maintain outside stairs and porches so they are free of holes, cracks and other conditions that may cause an accidental hazard. keep accessory buildings in good repair and free from any condition that may create a health, fire or accident hazard. maintain steps, walks, driveways, parking spaces and similar areas of a yard to provide safe passage under normal use and weather conditions. 1 click here to see the back 1 click here to see the back 1 click here to see the back 2 click here to see the back 2 click here to see the back 2 click here to see the back 3 click here to see the back 3 click here to see the back 3 click here to see the back pride of ownership the most common concerns are:

proper storage and disposal of waste waste storage and disposal proper storage and disposal of waste every municipality throughout new brunswick has by-laws outlining the proper storage and disposal of waste, recycling and compost. when waste is not stored properly it causes rodent problems, health concerns and may result in a hefty fine from your municipality. this will also risk damaging your relationship with your neighbours. it is recommended that you become familiar with the waste collection schedule for your neighbourhood. a simple google search of your city or town's name with the words "waste collection schedule", should render the information you need. many cities and towns now offer downloadable apps specific to waste collection. to avoid accumulation of waste on your property, please refer to the tips below. get to know your waste collection schedule and add reminders to your calendar. get to know your waste collection schedule and add reminders to your calendar. make sure organic materials are placed in the proper bags or bins for pick up. practice proper recycling by cleaning and sorting item when adding to bins or bags. put yard waste out at appropriate times throughout the year. never put hazardous waste or electronics out for pick up. instead find a depot close to you who accepts these items. bulk waste collection of items such as appliances and furniture are available in most cities or towns. you will find specific information on collection of these items through your city or town's web page. fredericton restore 506-462-4881 saint john restore 506-635-7867 moncton restore 506- 384-4664 miramichi restore 506-773-3265 if appliances are in working order or furniture is gently used without rips or stains, consider donating items to your local habitat for humanity restore. our locations may offer pick up services in your area!

dangerous and unsightly premises please keep your property clean and free of waste, including: junk, rubbish and refuse. derelict vehicles, pieces of equipment, or machinery. dilapidated buildings. accumulation of wood shavings, sawdust or other flammable material.

incorrect maintain your property by properly disposing of large trash and hazardous waste, and keeping stairs/decks safe. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct maintain your property by properly disposing of large trash and hazardous waste, and keeping stairs/decks safe. continue continue continue continue continue continue best practices to maintaining your property are: dispose of bulk waste according to your city or township’s bulk waste policies. maintain outside stairs and decks so they don’t cause accidental hazards. dispose of hazardous waste at local depots. dispose of bulk waste according to your city or township’s bulk waste policies. maintain outside stairs and decks so they don’t cause accidental hazards. dispose of hazardous waste at local depots. post a caution sign if stairs or decks become unsafe. store all bulk waste on your property under a tarp so it’s out of sight. throw hazardous waste out with regular garbage. post a caution sign if and stairs so they do not cause accidental hazards. leave discarded furniture at the side of the road until someone collects it. submit submit submit submit submit submit

other things to consider the average dog will cost you $3000 or more a year, including food and veterinary bills. can you comfortably afford the proper care needed with extra saved for emergency vet bills? are you willing to devote the necessary time for training and caring for your pet? will you supervise the animal’s behavior at all times, especially with visitors and small children? will you see to it that all animals, when outside, will be leashed? will you clean up your animal's waste (feces) in your yard and while on walks? will you have your pets spayed or neutered? dogs, cats, birds and other animals are wonderful companions. many people love pets. however, not everyone finds animals appealing. when pets are not properly trained and controlled by their owners, they can ruin relationships with your neighbours and community members. before getting an animal, you should be aware of what it takes to make it a good member of your family, and of your neighbourhood. responsible pet ownership responsible pet ownership

insurance insurance is a very important part of being a good neighbour. we often think of insurance as help when something goes wrong for us. it also helps protect our neighbours. if you own a house you need to protect it and yourself from possible losses. those losses can happen a number of ways… water - theft - flood - snow, or wind damagelegal liability a home insurance program provides coverage for those losses and makes sure that you have enough money to rebuild or replace what was lost. if you don’t have insurance, you may find yourself in a situation where you cannot fix your home and there will be an effect on the properties around you. make certain your property insurance carries $2,000,000 liability. that way, if someone is injured while on your property your home ownership policy will assist with voluntary medical costs and insure you, should legal action be taken against you. having a solid understanding of your insurance policy before the need to use it, will help alleviate stress, should you need to make an insurance claim. habitat for humanity new brunswick believes your home ownership journey should be a happy and celebrated one! through thoughtfulness towards neighbours, abiding by the local by-laws and codes and being helpful within your neighbourhood, you will be well on your way to thriving in your community, year after year!

incorrect be a responsible pet owner by budgeting, socializing, training, and providing good care (food, water, love). don't let them roam or be aggressive. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct be a responsible pet owner by budgeting, socializing, training, and providing good care (food, water, love). don't let them roam or be aggressive. continue continue continue trained to interact with others. let your pet remain outdoors and freely roam the neighbourhood. understanding the biggest expense to pet ownership will be the purchase of your pet. ensure your pet is emergency preparedness emergencies can happen anytime, so it’s important to be prepared. keep key numbers—like police, fire, poison control, and utility services—easily accessible. teach children how to use them and ensure your household knows what to do in case of an emergency. preparation shows care not just for your home, but for your entire community. insurance awareness home insurance is crucial—it protects not only your property but also your neighbors from potential damage or liability. whether it’s from storms, theft, or accidents, being insured ensures you can recover without impacting others. understanding your policy in advance can save time and stress during emergencies. it's a responsible part of being a homeowner. respecting neighbors' rights and privacy everyone has the right to peace and privacy in their home. respect boundaries, noise levels, and by-laws related to property and fire safety. educate your children about staying within your yard and keep additions within property lines. small actions like these prevent conflict and build stronger neighborly bonds. responsible pet ownership pets can bring joy, but being a responsible owner is essential for harmony with your neighbors. before bringing home an animal, ask yourself if you can commit time, care, and finances. always leash pets in public and clean up after them. a well-behaved pet and a clean yard go a long way in keeping peace on your street. dangerous and unsightly premises keeping your property free from junk, broken-down vehicles, and unsafe structures is not just courteous—it’s required. an untidy yard can pose health and safety risks to you and your community. make sure your space is free of hazards like flammable materials and derelict buildings. a clean exterior reflects pride and prevents neighborhood tension. waste storage and disposal pride of ownership means taking care of your home and yard to reflect your commitment to the community and habitat for humanity’s values. this includes maintaining your lawn, clearing snow from walkways, and keeping your exterior tidy. it’s not just about appearance—it’s about safety and respect. by caring for your home, you protect your investment and positively represent your neighborhood. pride of ownership pride of ownership means taking care of your home and yard to reflect your commitment to the community and habitat for humanity’s values. this includes maintaining your lawn, clearing snow from walkways, and keeping your exterior tidy. it’s not just about appearance—it’s about safety and respect. by caring for your home, you protect your investment and positively represent your neighborhood. module review let us review before going through the knowledge check. click on the arrows to continue

wrapping up responsible homeownership includes maintaining your property, managing waste properly, and upholding safety standards to reflect pride of ownership and protect your investment. being a good neighbour means showing respect, empathy, and consideration—building strong community ties through everyday actions and mutual support. following local by-laws and preparing for emergencies ensures you stay compliant, avoid conflicts or fines, and protect your household and community in unexpected situations. in this module you have learned:
end of module click next to end the module. your commitment to being a respectful and considerate neighbor helps build a stronger, more connected community. congratulations on completing the module!

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:
